--- title: Obturator Internus Muscle (OI) --- ![Hip and Thigh Muscles @OpenStaxAnatomyPhysiology2022](/The Archive/Images/OpenStax Anatomy and Physiology 2e/fig11.29 Hip and Thigh Muscles.jpeg){#fig-openstax-fig11.29} ![Muscles of the gluteal and posterior femoral region @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Myology/image434 Muscles of the gluteal and posterior femoral regions.gif){#fig-gray1918-image434} ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Pelvic floor muscles @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 - Ch57 piriformis, obturator internus, gemellus, obturator externus, quadratus femoris muscles @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 - Neuman @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 ::: ::: {#tbl-oian-obturator-internus .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Obturator Internus Obturator membrane and its bony boundaries Medial surface of Greater Trochanter Nerve to Obturator internus
L5 - S1		 Hip: ER, Extension, Abduction, Stabilization
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} The OI originates from the Inner surface of the obturator membrane and its bony boundaries [@gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020]. # Path {#path} From its [origin](#origin) the OI courses through the pelvic cavity posteriorly and exits through the *lesser sciatic foramen* @jonesProjectFoundations2025. At the *lesser sciatic foramen* the OI tendon bends sharply to continue laterally to run parallel with the [piriformis]({{< var ref-piriformis.path >}}) to its [insertion](#insertion) on the medial surface of the greater trochanter @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Insertion {#insertion} Medial surface of the greater trochanter @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} Sacral plexus ([L5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l5 >}}), [S1]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s1 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - External rotation and extension of the hip joint (also active in abduction, depending on the joint’s position) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Stabilizes hip joint -DrK # Function “Ultrasound ­guided EMG analysis of the obturator internus and several other external rotator muscles in 10 human subjects.98 The obturator internus was usually the first muscle to become active during a gradually increasing isometric effort to abduct and externally rotate the hip.” @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 # Palpation {#palpation} Due to the common insertion of the [inferior gemellus]({{< var ref-inferior-gemellus.palpation >}}), obturator internus, and [superior gemellus]({{< var ref-superior-gemellus.insertion >}}) it is difficult to differentiate between these structures during palpation. Instead, I just palpate and treat these as a group. - Palpate the [piriformis]({{< var ref-piriformis.palpation >}}) and the [quadratus femoris]({{< var ref-quadratus-femoris.palpation >}}). - Palpate the space between these two muscles, and there you should feel the [inferior gemellus]({{< var ref-inferior-gemellus.palpation >}}), obturator internus, and [superior gemellus]({{< var ref-superior-gemellus.path >}}). # Dysfunction - Gemelli-obturator internus syndrome # Pain Referral Pattern According to Myers, there is no pain referral pattern for the obturator internus @myersClinicalCounterstrain2012. Myers does state that it is clinically correllated with pain in the coccyx and posterior thigh @myersClinicalCounterstrain2012. # Obturator Internus Syndrome {#obturator-internus-syndrome} # Stretch Child's Pose stretch can be used to stretch the Obturator Internus muscle. By cueing the knees to stay straight instead of moving into hip ER, this better stretches the obturator internus. # Exercises - FAddER Contract-Relax - Therapist assisted - Self-Stretch
